statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.headline: Oregon 52, Washington State 50
article.story: PULLMAN, Wash. (AP) -- Malik Hairston takes his time warming up, but he only needed the last 12 seconds of the game to shoot down Washington State. Hairston, limited to six points in the first 39-plus minutes, sank two 3-point field goals in the final 12 seconds -- including the game-winner from the left corner with four-tenths of a second left -- to lift Oregon past Washington State 52-50 Thursday night. "I understand I've got to do a little more in the first half," said Hairston, who has scored 83 points in the past four games, but just 18 before halftime. "But to be able to come through down the stretch for my basketball team is a good feeling." Jordan Kent, an Oregon football player who had scored just three points in nine games, led the Ducks (10-8, 4-2 Pac-10) with season highs of 13 points and 12 rebounds. Hairston added 12 points, and Aaron Brooks scored 10 points and set up Hairston for the game-winning shot in Oregon's ninth consecutive win over WSU. Josh Akognon led Washington State (9-6, 2-4) with 18 points. Robbie Cowgill scored 12 for the Cougars, who have now lost three games in a row -- by a total of nine points. "They were stunned," WSU coach Dick Bennett said of his players, who have made a habit of losing close games during his three-year tenure. "There wasn't much I could say. I just said, 'I'm sorry you keep having to go through this.' " WSU supporters claimed Brooks traveled on his drive through the lane before dishing to Hairston for the deciding basket. "He looked like he got away with one," WSU guard Kyle Weaver said. "We got him into a bad situation, maybe a travel," Bennett said. "I don't think he did," Hairston said, "but I'm not going to look back. We got the W." Neither team led by more than four points. Oregon held a 29-27 lead at the half. Two Akognon free throws had pushed Washington State ahead 50-46 with 25 seconds left in the game before Hairston connected twice from deep. "He's our stud," Oregon coach Ernie Kent said. "They made the plays they had to make and we didn't," Bennett said. Hairston's 3-pointers were sandwiched around a missed free throw by Washington State's Ivory Clark in the bonus situation with 10.7 seconds left. "If they make two free throws, it completely changes the complexion of the game," Kent said. Oregon outrebounded Washington State 39-22, including 16-4 on the offensive glass. The points and rebounds were season lows for WSU. Oregon tied its season low for points. "I think it's the inability to rebound the ball that really cost us the game," Bennett said. The Cougars continue to play without second-leading scorer Derrick Low, who has a broken foot. Both teams shot 50 percent from the field in the first half, but dropped below 40 percent in the second half. Oregon, which won its third consecutive game, shot 42 percent for the game, compared to 44 percent for WSU. Oregon had been 0-6 away from home, and WSU had been 6-0 at Friel Court.
